item.title: Project Euler 101: Optimum Polynomial
item.description: Problem Statement Given the first \(k\) terms of a sequence, it is impossible to say what the next one will be, as there are infinitely many polynomial functions that interpolate (that is, go through) each of these \(k\) points. As an example, consider the perfect cubes \(1,8,27,64,\ldots\), given by \(P(n) = n^3\). We try to find an interpolating polynomial, operating by the principle of “simpler is better.” If we were given just the first term, the simplest possibility is that the sequence is constant.
